Arazi, the star-crossed former wonder colt, had been scheduled to make yet another comeback today in the 1,600-meter Prix du Moulin. Instead, Arazi had to be scratched after bruising his right hock in his regular stall on Saturday night. Plagued by Bad Luck
"It's not serious at all, but his hock was a bit inflamed this morning," said the French trainer. "It's bad luck. Bad luck seems to follow me lately."

Arazi's decline began last November when he underwent arthroscropic surgery to remove bone chips in both knees. Then after easily winning a low-level, 1,600-meter race in France upon his return in April, he entered the Kentucky Derby as the overwhelming favorite and finished a stunning eighth. And after a six-week layoff, he returned in June and placed fourth in the St. James Palace Stakes in Ascot.
"What makes today so disappointing is that I know the horse was on top of his form," Boutin said. "He's been training beautifully and I felt very confident about his chances."

Boutin remains guardedly optimistic and says that if the hock injury heals quickly, Arazi will run in either the 2,000-meter Prix du Prince d'Orange at Longchamp on Sept. 20 or in the mile-long Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot on Sept. 26. The Ascot race is more likely because it is shorter. After that, the goal remains the one-and-a-quarter mile Breeders' Cup Classic at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla., on Oct. 31.
